title: What literary devices make poetry beautiful? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are many aspects that make poetry beautiful. Literary and poetic devices are absolute keystones of that beauty. Though, writing good poetry is like making incredible meal. Just because you have all of the right ingredients doesn't mean that you'll end up with a world-class entree. First, you do need to learn the systems. I think one part of poetry that people don't give enough credence to is the importance of meter. —Meter —  If you think about the difference between a rap song and a romance ballad (minus the actual music), most of it will be in the structural meter. The way the words are said and emphasized vastly differs. Poetry is just the same. Whether you're dealing with a sestina or Haiku or free verse poem, a lot of the beauty comes in the metered structure that the poet crafts. For example, The Iliad (like most Greek poetry) was written in dactylic hexameter. I love opening of the Iliad: RAGE:                Sing, Goddess, Achilles’ rage, Black and murderous, that cost the Greeks Incalculable pain, pitched countless souls Of heroes into Hades’ dark, And left their bodies to rot as feasts For dogs and birds, as Zeus’ will was done.      Begin with the clash between Agamemnon--  The Greek warlord--and godlike Achilles. —Repetition—  Repetition is a very powerful device in poetic language. Actually, John F. Kennedy (US President) was very poetic is his speeches (or rather, his speech writer @Ted Sorensen was). Here is a selection from an article analyzing his speeches.[1] Sometimes, those lists followed the “rule of three,” or “tricolon,” making sure to use three images, arguments or examples. Other times, Kennedy made longer lists by using “anaphora”: repeating one word several times to expand a list and continue an over-long sentence well past the rules of grammar. Kennedy often used the classical literary device, “chiasmus,” to invert the word order in a sentence and make a new meaning. Consider how Kennedy uses the rule of three and chiasmus to begin his inaugural address:  —Imagery and Representations—  One of the most powerful building blocks can come for really powerful emotive poetry is imagery and representation. One of my favorite forms is Synecdoche. Synecdoche is a literary device in which a part of something represents the whole or it may use a whole to represent a part. Here is an example from Percy Bysshe Shelley: “Tell that its sculptor well those passions readWhich yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,The hand that mocked them.” In this case, the hand represents the sculptor that passed on the “gift” of life to lifeless things. —Simple, Raw Emotion—  Sometimes you just have certain poems that just hit home with their raw emotion. This why the poetry of Rupi Kaur resonates with a lot of people, even though some take umbrage with its form . But, one of the emotional masters was and always will be Maya Angelou: You may write me down in history With your bitter, twisted lies, You may trod me in the very dirt But still, like dust, I’ll rise.  Does my sassiness upset you? Why are you beset with gloom? ‘Cause I walk like I’ve got oil wells Pumping in my living room.  Just like moons and like suns, With the certainty of tides, Just like hopes springing high, Still I’ll rise. She most certainly uses the power of poetic structure. But wow, that just strikes a powerful chord. Like dust, I’ll rise… Hope this was helpful Best, Brenton Footnotes[1] The art of words—what JFK can teach us about speech writing - Office Blogs

I don’t think there’s a single definitive answer to this question. Poetry and beauty are both very subjective experiences. That being said, some of the devices I think make poetry beautiful are: Extended metaphors - “Hope” by Emily Dickinson Hope is the thing with feathers That perches in the soul, And sings the tune—without the words, And never stops at all Juxtaposition - Romeo and Juliet by William Shakespeare, Act 1, Scene V (not really a poem, but still an effective use of juxtaposition) O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright! It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope’s ear Romeo is praising Juliet here, saying that the brightness of her face could teach the torches how to burn bright, and that against Ethiopian skin, she would seem to be a sparkly jewel. Not sure if I would enjoy being told that my face was shiny, but the image gets across pretty well. Symbols - “Ozymandias” by Percy Bysshe Shelley And on the pedestal these words appear “My name is Ozymandias, king of kings: Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!” Nothing beside remains. Round the decay Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare The lone and level sands stretch far away The ruined statue of Ozymandias and its location (another epithet for Ramses II) represents where vanity of man gets you. The same place everyone ends up, in lonely death. The “king of kings” seems to realize after his life that even his works can (and did) become a “colossal wreck”, and that his vanity only isolated him in life.

Beauty in poetry is often defined through the style of the writing, rather than the devices. However, useful ones for me alliterative, consonance, personification, metaphor, anaphora, inverted syntax and vivid imagery. Below, I have written a short (and rather poor) poem that hopefully illustrates this point: On the moors, Where the petals ploughed the fields, Where the grass groaned the greys of night away. Where the dew of day moistened the ground with an oblique petrachor. This was the moors.

Literary Devices doesn't matter much in a poetry. It is the emotions and the way you express your feelings makes it beautiful. Other aspects are its Structure, Rhymic scheme, Sentences, Vocabulary etc. Literary Devices are there to help you make a poem better and to present it in a profound way. It us up to the poet whether to use various literary devices or not. According to me ‘Personification’ is the one which makes a poem alive. It is a literary device in which an inanimate object or animal is given the attributes a human.

There are alot of devices which make poetry beautiful, like meter, assonance, alliteration, Rhyme scheme, metaphor, synecdoche, consonance, tone, mood, cacophony, euphony, personification, imagery, symbols etc.
